clinical_study.brief_title: CALLSAS Study: Effect of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure Treatment for Obstructive Apnea on Smartphone Usage Habits
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure Treatment for Obstructive Apnea on Smartphone Usage Habits: the Callsas Study

brief_summary.textblock: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment improves sleepiness, depression and social activities in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). This evolution can be captured from changes in smartphone usage habits coupled with a mobile-based services. The aim of this study is to assess the impact of CPAP treatment on smartphone usage habits in OSA patients.

detailed_description.textblock:
Callsas is a prospective study embarking newly diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea patients initiated to CPAP treatment.
The primary objective is to analyze the modifications in smartphone usage habits before and after CPAP treatment.
Secondary objectives:
- Correlation between changes in smartphone usage habits and evolution of sleepiness
- Correlation between changes in smartphone usage habits and evolution of depression scale
- Correlation between changes in smartphone usage habits and evolution of quality of life
- Correlation between changes in physical activity measured by smartphones and evolution of physical activity objectively measured by actigraphy and gait platform
- Correlation between smartphone usage habits and CPAP adherence

primary_outcome.measure: Effect of CPAP on smartphone usage habits indices
primary_outcome.time_frame: from 6 months before CPAP treatment until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation
primary_outcome.description: Changes in indices of smartphone usage habits

secondary_outcome.measure: Time course evolution of smartphone usage habits indices and evolution of sleepiness
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from CPAP initiation until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation

secondary_outcome.measure: Time course evolution of smartphone usage habits indices and evolution of depression
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from CPAP initiation until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of depression by Pichot scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Time course evolution of smartphone usage habits indices and evolution of quality of life
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from CPAP initiation until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of quality of life by SF-36

secondary_outcome.measure: Time course evolution of smartphone usage habits indices and evolution of locomotion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from CPAP initiation until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation
secondary_outcome.description: patterns of locomotion objectively measured by a gait platform

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from CPAP initiation until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation
secondary_outcome.description: Time course evolution of CPAP adherence assessed by telemonitoring versus time course evolution of smartphone usage habits

secondary_outcome.measure: Access to care as a predictor of CPAP adherence
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from CPAP initiation until 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation
secondary_outcome.description: Care access questionnaire developed by ODENORE and National French insurance

secondary_outcome.measure: Effect of food habit with CPAP treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At CPAP initiation and at 6 months after CPAP treatment initiation

arm_group.description: All included OSA patients are going to be treated by CPAP

intervention.description: All patients included will be treated by CPAP

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Newly diagnosed OSA patients initiated on CPAP
- Customers of Orange (or Sosh) for mobile and/or fixed-line telephony
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women
- Patients with disease not allowing to realize functional and locomotion tests
